Posts.Title: Listen to your gut WannaCruize AnnBR

Posts.Content: May 13, 2013 10:27PM - edited May 14, 2013 09:34AM by AnnBR Hello Stage 1 sisters! I've been a member for several months now, but just discovered this group so I'm jumping right in. It's been comforting to me to read about your journeys and to know that indeed, we have each others backs. I had a UXM in Dec. of last year and am having my remaining breast removed on May 22. At the time I had my UXM, I made the decision not to remove my other breast. I consulted with an oncologist of course, but not with a plastic surgeon. The PS I chose for reconstruction is 3.5 hours away and I saw him in Feb. of this year. Prior to my appointment, I was required to send him my initial MRI which was read by one of their radiologists. A follow up mammogram and ultrasound were clear, but my first BC was not detected by those tests so I decided to forgo a biopsy and have it removed. In hindsight, I wish I would have made the decision for a BMX in Dec., but I am not going to beat myself up. I know it was the right decision for me at the time. I'm not sure why I am sharing all of this, maybe just to say that BC forces you to make some tough decisions (as many of you know!) Thanks ladies, you are all so wonderful! Ann

Posts.Content: May 19, 2013 05:36PM AnnBR wrote: Thanks ladies! I appreciate your words of support. Today I went to church and asked for prayers, which is always a comfort to me. I came home, washed 2 loads of laundry, planted my flowers, cleaned the house and got a few casseroles in the freezer. My DH is a great help so my to do list was done in half the time. I have a SNB scheduled for Tuesday and the mastectomy/TE surgery is Wednesday. I am anxious to get this next step behind me. Oh, I also took a picture of my remaining breast, is that crazy or what?!? Ann

Posts.Title: Just got Biopsy results Nellie5 new2bc

Posts.Content: May 21, 2017 05:30PM - edited May 21, 2017 05:33PM by AnnBR Thanks ladies! You ARE a cool bunch. I'm on Ibrance, and monthly injections of Xgeva & Faslodex. So far so good. I decided I need to plan out my celebration of life service so I am writing down my wishes and getting photos in order, because my husband will be clueless and I don't want my son and daughter to tackle this. Once my affairs are in order, I plan on living a nice long life!
Posts.Title: Newbie here & reaching out AnnBR AnnBR

Posts.Content: AnnBR wrote: Hello everyone! Two weeks ago I was told that active cancer cells were found in my spine and I heard the words that no one wants to hear, 'It can't be cured.' Wow. I went from Stage 1 to Stage 4 in 4-1/2 years and I had a low oncotype score when I was first diagnosed. Geez! What happened?! But knowing it can be treated like a chronic disease and that there's many treatment options havegiven me hope. I really am at peace with the diagnosis. I have never been treated with chemo as my Mayo team says the long term side effects outweigh the benefits and being ER+ and PR+ and HER2- is more successfully treated by radiation and hormone therapy. I'm not questioning my amazing team but I'm curious if others have had a similar diagnosis and treatments? Thank you! Ann I have BATTLE SCARS on my body...but I have a PEACE in my HEART. Dx 11/15/2012, IDC, Left, 1cm, Stage IA, Grade 3, 0/3 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Surgery 12/8/2012 Mastectomy Hormonal Therapy 1/16/2013 Surgery 4/29/2014 Reconstruction (left): DIEP flap; Reconstruction (right): DIEP flap Hormonal Therapy 5/12/2014 Femara (letrozole) Radiation Therapy 6/1/2014 Breast, Lymph nodes Dx 5/2017, IDC, Stage IV, metastasized to bone, ER+/PR+, HER2- Hormonal Therapy Faslodex (fulvestrant) Targeted Therapy Ibrance (palbociclib) Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Newbie here & reaching out AnnBR AnnBR

Posts.Content: Dec 5, 2012 11:20PM AnnBR wrote: I am new to this site as I was recently diagnosed with BC. My surgeon had been keeping an eye on a slight indention of my left nipple for awhile but he never felt anything. After six months he said, "let's get in there and put both our minds to rest." When he called me two days later with the news, I was shocked. It became all consuming until I began to educate myself, making me feel like I am in control. All I know for now is that it is Stage 1, grade 2-3, ER+, HER2-. I had an appointment with an oncologist last week who ordered an MRI, which is scheduled for this Friday. For the most part I am calm and am trying not to dwell on it, but then I have surges of panic where my mind races to worse case scenario. I meet with the oncologist next week and she will recommend which surgical option would be best for me. This waiting game is so hard! I am so glad I found this site, reading through the posts has been very comforting and I know I am not alone!
